docs.title: 📂 Beef
docs.text:
Here are the recipes in this collection:

  • Colorado-Style Tri-Tip Chile Colorado

docs.title: Colorado-Style Tri-Tip Chile Colorado
docs.text:
(Locked-In Final Version — Tri-Tip • Roasted Poblano • Abuelita • Masa)

Recipe Details

  • Yield: 6–8 servings
  • Texture target: Deep, silky, chile-forward sauce that clings without becoming heavy

docs.title: Beef & Oil
docs.text:
• 3 lb tri-tip roast, trimmed and cut into 1–1¼-inch cubes
  • 2–3 tbsp neutral oil
  • 2 tsp kosher salt (Diamond Crystal; ~1½ tsp if Morton)
  • 1–1½ tsp black pepper

docs.title: Dried Chile Sauce
docs.text:
• 5 dried guajillo chiles
  • 4 dried ancho chiles
  • 3 dried pasilla chiles
  • (Optional heat) 1–2 chiles de árbol
  • 1 large onion, divided:
    • half charred for the sauce
    • half diced for the pot
  • 6 cloves garlic, charred
  • 1½ tsp Mexican oregano
  • 1½ tsp ground cumin
  • 1 tsp kosher salt
  • 1½–2 cups chile soaking liquid, as needed

docs.title: Vegetables & Aromatics
docs.text:
• 1 poblano pepper, roasted, peeled, seeded, and chopped
  • (Optional) ¼–½ tsp freeze-dried shallot, lightly crushed

docs.title: Braising & Body
docs.text:
• ~4 cups low-sodium beef broth
  • 1 tbsp tomato paste (optional, for added body)

docs.title: Chocolate & Thickener
docs.text:
• ¼ tablet Abuelita chocolate (≈ 25–30 g), chopped
  • 2–3 tbsp masa harina, added as a slurry
  • ¼ cup water

docs.title: Finishing Adjustments
docs.text:
• ¼–½ tsp brown sugar, only if bitterness appears
  • ¾ tsp apple cider vinegar, plus optional additional ¼–½ tsp to taste
  • Salt, as needed

docs.title: 1. Toast and Soak the Chiles
docs.text: Remove stems and seeds from all dried chiles. Toast briefly in a dry pan until fragrant, taking care not to burn them. Cover with hot water and soak 15–20 minutes until fully pliable.

docs.title: 2. Char the Aromatics
docs.text: Char half of the onion (cut into large pieces) and the garlic cloves in a dry pan until well blistered. Set aside.

docs.title: 3. Blend and Strain the Chile Sauce
docs.text:
Blend the soaked chiles, charred onion and garlic, oregano, cumin, salt, and about 1½ cups of the soaking liquid until completely smooth. Strain to remove skins and seeds.

Target consistency: heavy cream.

docs.title: 4. Roast the Poblano
docs.text: Roast the poblano until blistered. Steam for 10 minutes, then peel, seed, and chop. Set aside.

docs.title: 5. Brown the Beef
docs.text: Season the tri-tip with salt and pepper. Brown in batches in neutral oil over medium-high heat until deeply colored. Remove to a plate.

docs.title: 6. Build the Base
docs.text: In the same pot, sauté the diced onion with a pinch of salt until soft. If using, stir in the tomato paste and cook 1–2 minutes until darkened. Add the strained chile sauce and stir to combine.

docs.title: 7. Braise
docs.text: Return the beef and any accumulated juices to the pot. Add the roasted poblano and beef broth, using enough liquid to mostly submerge the meat without drowning it. Bring to a gentle simmer, cover, and cook 2–2½ hours, stirring occasionally, until the beef is tender but holds its shape.

docs.title: 8. Add the Chocolate
docs.text: During the final 20–30 minutes, stir in the chopped Abuelita chocolate. Simmer until fully melted and integrated. The effect should be warming and round, never overtly sweet or chocolate-forward.

docs.title: 9. Optional Micro-Lift
docs.text: If the mid-palate feels slightly hollow, add ¼–½ tsp crushed freeze-dried shallot and simmer about 10 minutes. This should disappear quietly into the sauce.

docs.title: 10. Thicken with Masa
docs.text: Whisk 2 tbsp masa harina with ¼ cup water to form a slurry. Stir into the pot and simmer 10–15 minutes. For slightly more body, add up to 1 additional tablespoon of slurry. Avoid exceeding this—too much masa will mute the chile character.

docs.title: 11. Final Balance
docs.text:
Taste and adjust deliberately: * If bitterness remains, add ¼–½ tsp brown sugar. * If brightness is lacking, add ¾ tsp apple cider vinegar, simmer briefly, and retaste. Add an additional ¼–½ tsp only if needed. * Adjust salt to sharpen the chile and beef.

The final profile should feel deep, clean, bright, and gently rounded.

docs.title: 12. Rest and Serve
docs.text:
Rest off heat for 10–15 minutes to allow the sauce to settle. Serve with warm tortillas, lime wedges, and cilantro. A light crumble of queso fresco is optional.

Avoid heavy sour cream, which dulls the finish.

Chef's Notes

  • ~4 cups stock yields a saucy, competition-style texture.
  • 2–3 tbsp masa provides silkiness without heaviness.
  • ¼ tablet Abuelita adds depth without sweetness.
  • Vinegar is the final tuning tool—use it precisely.

docs.title: 📂 Fermentation

Here are the recipes in this collection:

docs.title: Full-Sour Pickles (Katz's Deli Style)
docs.text:
Delicious Full-Sour Pickles (Katz's Deli Style) recipe

Recipe Details

  • Yield: ** 2 Quart Jars
  • Prep time: ** ~20 mins
  • Texture target: TBD
  • Cook time: ** 0 mins (Fermentation: 10-14 days)

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
For 1 lb cucumbers (split between 2 jars): - [ ] 1 lb mini seedless cucumbers, washed, blossom ends trimmed - [ ] 4 cloves garlic, smashed (2 per jar) - [ ] 2 tsp black peppercorns (1 tsp per jar) - [ ] 2 tsp coriander seeds (1 tsp per jar) - [ ] 1/2 tsp mustard seeds (optional, divide between jars) - [ ] 2 bay leaves (1 per jar) - [ ] 2 dried red chilis (optional, for spice—1 per jar) - [ ] 4 sprigs fresh dill (2 per jar) or 1 tsp dill seed per jar - [ ] 2 grape leaves or black tea bags (1 per jar — optional but helps with crispness)

Basic 2.5% brine: - [ ] 2 cups non-chlorinated water - [ ] 1.5 tbsp kosher or sea salt (without iodine or anti-caking agents)

docs.title: Step 1: Sterilize Jars and Equipment
docs.text:
1. Wash jars, lids, airlocks, and any weights in hot soapy water.
  2. Rinse well.
  3. To sanitize:
  4. Option 1: Pour boiling water over jars and parts, let sit 2–3 minutes.
  5. Option 2: Soak in a mix of 1 tbsp bleach per gallon of water for 5 minutes, then rinse thoroughly with clean water.
  6. Let everything air dry on a clean towel.

docs.title: Step 2: Make the Brine
docs.text:
1. Dissolve salt in water completely.
  2. Taste it — should be pleasantly salty.
  3. Double this if needed; you may need ~2.5–3 cups total to fill both jars.

docs.title: Step 3: Pack the Jars
docs.text:
1. Add spices, garlic, dill, and grape leaf/tea bag to bottom of each jar.
  2. Pack cucumbers in tightly but gently — avoid breaking them.
  3. Pour brine over until everything is fully submerged. Leave 1 inch headspace.
  4. Add fermentation weights or a small brine-filled zip-top bag to keep cucumbers submerged.

docs.title: Step 4: Attach the Airlock Lids
docs.text:
1. Make sure airlocks are filled with water to the fill line.
  2. Insert into lid grommets.
  3. Screw lids on finger-tight — don’t over-tighten.

docs.title: Step 5: Fermentation
docs.text:
1. Place jars on a plate or tray (brine may bubble over).
  2. Keep at room temperature (65–75°F) out of direct sunlight.
  3. Check daily:
  4. Bubbles? Good!
  5. Brine cloudy? Normal!
  6. Floating bits? Push down or remove.
  7. Taste at Day 5–7. Full sour often takes 10–14 days.

docs.title: Step 6: Finish and Store
docs.text:
1. Once they taste sour, garlicky, and “deli-style”:
  2. Remove weights.
  3. Swap lids for regular mason jar lids (or keep airlock on).
  4. Refrigerate. They’ll keep months in the fridge and flavor will deepen.

docs.title: Notes:
docs.text:
• If you see white film (kahm yeast), it’s harmless — skim it off.
  • Avoid mold (blue/green/black fuzz) by keeping everything submerged.
  • Save leftover brine for next batch or use in salad dressings.

docs.title: Calculating Brine Percentage
docs.text:
To make brine for any amount of water, use a scale: Water Weight (g) x Percentage = Salt Weight (g)

Example for 2.5% brine: - 1,000g water x 0.025 = 25g salt - 500g water x 0.025 = 12.5g salt

Tags: #fermentation

docs.title: House Hard Ginger Beer
docs.text:
(Airlock + Cold Crash Method — Alcoholic Ginger Beer)

Recipe Details

  • Yield: 1 gallon
  • Target ABV: ~4–4.5%
  • Carbonation: Medium, beer-like
  • Profile: Smooth ginger heat, lightly sweet to semi-dry, bright citrus finish

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 12 oz (340 g) fresh ginger (Scrubbed, skin on, sliced into ⅛–¼” medallions, lightly crushed)
  • 2½ cups (500 g) white sugar (Fermentable base)
  • ¼ cup (2–3 lemons) lemon juice (Adds acidity & brightness)
  • To 1 gallon water (Filtered preferred)
  • ½ tsp champagne yeast (Clean, high attenuation yeast)

docs.title: Equipment
docs.text:
• 1-gallon glass fermenter
  • Stopper + airlock
  • Large pot
  • Strainer (optional)
  • Siphon/racking cane
  • Swing-top bottles (~16 oz)
  • Measuring spoon (½ tsp)

docs.title: 1. Ginger Extraction
docs.text:
1. Add to pot:
    • 6–7 oz sliced ginger
    • 2½ cups sugar
    • ~2 quarts water
  2. Bring to gentle simmer (not a rolling boil).
  3. Simmer 20 minutes.
  4. Remove from heat. Add remaining ginger (and optional lemon zest).
  5. Cool to warm.

docs.title: 2. Fermenter Setup
docs.text:
1. Strain into fermenter (or leave slices for stronger ginger).
  2. Add lemon juice.
  3. Top up with cool water to 1 gallon total.
  4. Ensure liquid is below 90°F (32°C).
  5. Pitch ½ tsp champagne yeast.
  6. Seal with airlock.

docs.title: 3. Primary Fermentation
docs.text:
Duration: 4 days at room temperature (65–75°F ideal)

Signs of healthy fermentation: * Airlock bubbling within 12–24 hours * Ginger pieces rising and falling * Thin foam ring forming

By Day 4: * ~4–4.5% ABV * Light sweetness remaining * Ginger flavor smooth and integrated

docs.title: 4. Cold Crash
docs.text:
1. Move fermenter to fridge.
  2. Keep airlock installed.
  3. Cold crash 48 hours.

Purpose: Yeast and sediment drop out; clarifies liquid; stabilizes sweetness & alcohol level.

docs.title: 5. Rack & Bottle
docs.text:
1. Siphon clear liquid off sediment.
  2. Bottle into clean swing-tops.

Priming Sugar (for carbonation): Add to each 16 oz bottle: - [ ] ½ teaspoon white sugar

Produces medium, beer-like carbonation with low pressure risk.

docs.title: 6. Bottle Conditioning
docs.text:
• Store bottles at room temperature.
  • Carbonation develops in 3–7 days.

First Check: Chill one bottle on Day 4 or 5, then open: * Light fizz → wait longer * Steady bubbles → ready * Strong rush → refrigerate all bottles

Once ready, refrigerate all bottles.

Final Profile

  • Alcohol: ~4–4.5% ABV
  • Sweetness: Lightly sweet / semi-dry
  • Ginger Heat: Smooth, warming, not harsh
  • Carbonation: Crisp, controlled, beer-like

Future Adjustments

  • More ginger bite: Increase ginger to 14–16 oz.
  • Drier finish: Extend primary to 5–6 days.
  • More carbonation: Use ¾ tsp priming sugar per bottle.
  • Lower alcohol: Reduce sugar to 2 cups.

docs.title: Lacto-Fermented Red Onions
docs.text:
Delicious Lacto-Fermented Red Onions recipe

Recipe Details

  • Yield: ** 1 Quart Jar
  • Prep time: ** ~15 mins
  • Texture target: TBD
  • Cook time: ** 0 mins (Fermentation: 5-7 days)

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
For 1 quart jar: - [ ] 1–2 red onions, peeled and sliced into rings or half-moons - [ ] 1 garlic clove (optional, adds depth) - [ ] 1/2 tsp black peppercorns (optional) - [ ] 1 bay leaf (optional) - [ ] 1 tsp coriander seeds or mustard seeds (optional) - [ ] 1 black tea bag (for crunch if you like — optional for onions)

Brine: - [ ] 2 cups water (dechlorinated) - [ ] 1 tbsp kosher salt (slightly less salty than the cucumbers — ~2% solution is better for onions)

You can also reuse the leftover brine if it’s fresh and not slimy — just top off with more water and salt if needed.

docs.title: Method
docs.text:
1. Slice onions and pack into the jar with any desired spices.
  2. Add brine until onions are submerged.
  3. Weigh them down — they float more than cucumbers! A fermentation weight or brine-filled zip-top bag works.
  4. Seal with your airlock lid.
  5. Ferment at room temperature for 5–7 days. Taste daily after day 3.
  6. Once tangy and translucent, move to the fridge. They’ll last months and keep getting better.

docs.title: Flavor Tips:
docs.text:
• Add a few slices of jalapeño or chili for spicy pickled onions.
  • Add a pinch of sugar for a mild sweet-and-sour deli vibe.
  • You can skip tannins (tea/grape leaf) for onions — they don’t need crunch like cukes do.

docs.title: Calculating Brine Percentage
docs.text:
To make brine for any amount of water, use a scale: Water Weight (g) x Percentage = Salt Weight (g)

Example for 2% brine (recommended for onions): - 1,000g water x 0.020 = 20g salt - 500g water x 0.020 = 10g salt

Tags: #fermentation

docs.title: 📂 Pizza
docs.text:
Here are the recipes in this collection:

  • Mushroom Bacon White Pizza

docs.title: Mushroom Bacon White Pizza
docs.text:
(Butternut Squash Crust — Gluten-Free, Thin & Crispy)

Savory, umami-forward white pizza designed to balance the natural sweetness of a thin, crispy butternut squash crust. Built specifically for a baking steel.

Recipe Details

  • Yield: 1 large 14-inch pizza or 2 thin 12-inch pizzas
  • Tags: Pizza, :gluten_free: Gluten-Free, Bacon

docs.title: Butternut Squash Crust
docs.text:
• 460 g cubed and roasted butternut squash, mashed smooth (measured after roasting)
  • 90 g tapioca starch
  • 70 g potato starch
  • 2 egg whites
  • 2½ tbsp olive oil
  • 1¾ tsp fine salt

docs.title: White Sauce
docs.text:
• ½ cup (4 oz) cream cheese, softened
  • 1–2 tbsp bacon fat (or olive oil)
  • 1 small garlic clove, finely grated
  • 1–2 tsp Truff Hot Sauce (or your favorite umami hot sauce)
  • Freshly ground black pepper
  • Salt, to taste (often unnecessary)

docs.title: Toppings
docs.text:
• 8–10 oz mushrooms (cremini or button), thinly sliced
  • 4–6 slices bacon
  • Low-moisture whole-milk mozzarella, shredded
  • Optional: grated Parmesan or provolone

docs.title: Crust
docs.text:
1. Roast the squash Roast butternut squash at 425°F / 220°C until fully tender and lightly browned.

  2. Measure and dry Weigh 460 g of squash after roasting. Mash until smooth. If the mash looks glossy or wet, press gently in a clean towel to remove excess moisture.

  3. Make the dough Mix squash, egg whites, olive oil, and salt until combined. Add tapioca and potato starches and mix into a very thick paste.

  4. Roll thin Roll dough between lightly oiled parchment to ~2 mm thickness. Remove top parchment.

  5. Par-bake On a fully preheated baking steel (top rack, 525–550°F), bake with parchment for 7–9 minutes, until set.

  6. Flip and finish Remove parchment, flip crust directly onto the steel, and bake 2–3 minutes more. Set aside.

docs.title: Toppings
docs.text:
1. Cook the bacon Cook bacon until just crisp. Chop and reserve the fat.

  2. Sauté the mushrooms Cook mushrooms in bacon fat over medium-high heat until all moisture is gone and mushrooms are lightly browned. Salt lightly at the end.

  3. Make the white sauce Mix cream cheese, bacon fat, garlic, lemon juice, black pepper, and salt (if needed) until smooth and spreadable.

docs.title: Assemble & Bake
docs.text:
1. Brush the crust lightly with olive oil.
  2. Spread a thin, even layer of white sauce.
  3. Add a light layer of mozzarella.
  4. Top with mushrooms and bacon.
  5. Finish with remaining mozzarella (and optional Parmesan or provolone).
  6. Bake at 475–500°F for 3–5 minutes, just until the cheese melts.
  7. Rest 1–2 minutes before slicing.

Notes

  • Keep toppings light and dry to prevent scorching on the steel.
  • Low-moisture mozzarella is essential for clean melting.
  • Bacon provides most of the salt; adjust only after baking.
  • Optional finish: cracked black pepper or chopped chives.

docs.title: 📂 Sauces
docs.text:
Here are the recipes in this collection:

  • Silky Cheese Sauce (8 oz)

docs.title: Silky Cheese Sauce (8 oz)
docs.text:
(With Optional Green Chiles — Milk • Butter • Sodium Citrate)

Recipe Details

  • Yield: ~1¾ cups (plenty for 4 people’s nachos)
  • Texture target: Glossy, pourable sauce that stays smooth as it cools

docs.title: Base
docs.text:
• ¾ cup whole milk
  • 1½ tbsp unsalted butter
  • 1¾ tsp sodium citrate (store-bought)
  • 8 oz cheese, freshly grated (cheddar, Colby, or a blend)

docs.title: Seasoning
docs.text:
• ½ tsp garlic powder
  • ½ tsp onion powder

docs.title: Optional (Highly Recommended)
docs.text: • 1 (4 oz) can diced green chiles, drained

docs.title: Optional to Finish
docs.text:
• Salt, only if needed
  • Splash of milk to loosen (as needed)

docs.title: 1. Build the Emulsifying Base
docs.text: In a small saucepan over medium heat, combine the milk, butter, and sodium citrate. Whisk until the butter is melted and the liquid is fully smooth and steaming. Do not boil.

docs.title: 2. Melt in the Cheese
docs.text:
Reduce heat to medium-low. Add the cheese in small handfuls, whisking constantly. Let each addition melt completely before adding more.

You’re looking for a smooth, glossy sauce with no graininess.

docs.title: 3. Season & Add Chiles
docs.text: Whisk in garlic powder and onion powder. Stir in drained green chiles if using.

docs.title: 4. Final Texture Check
docs.text:
• Too thick? Whisk in warm milk, 1–2 tbsp at a time.
  • Too thin? Add a small handful of cheese or simmer 30–60 seconds (gentle heat).
  • Seasoning? Taste and add salt only if the cheese you used is under-seasoned.

Storage & Reheating

  • Refrigerate up to 5 days.
  • Reheat on low heat (stovetop) or in short microwave bursts, whisking often.
  • Add a splash of milk as needed to restore flow.
Homemade Sodium Citrate (From Citric Acid + Baking Soda)

If you don’t have sodium citrate powder, you can make a liquid solution:

Ingredients * Food-grade citric acid * Baking soda (sodium bicarbonate) * Water

Ratio For every 10 g citric acid, use 13.1 g baking soda.

Method 1. Warm ½ cup water in a saucepan (hot but not boiling). 2. Dissolve the citric acid completely. 3. Add baking soda very slowly, stirring constantly (it will foam and fizz). 4. When additions cause little to no fizz, stop and simmer gently 2–3 minutes. 5. Cool and store in a jar in the fridge.

Use: If you want a consistent strength, reduce the liquid to about ½ cup total volume to concentrate it.

docs.title: Honey & Orange Glazed Salmon with Ginger
docs.text:
Delicious Honey & Orange Glazed Salmon with Ginger recipe

Recipe Details

  • Yield: ** 4-6 servings
  • Prep time: ** 30 mins (marinate) + prep
  • Texture target: TBD
  • Cook time: ** 12-15 mins

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1.5 lb salmon filets (with skin or without)
  • Zest and juice of 1 orange
  • 1 Tbsp grated fresh ginger
  • 1 Tbsp honey
  • 1 tsp salt
  • ½ tsp ground black pepper
  • 1 tbsp olive oil
  • Optional: 1 tsp ground coriander for warmth and depth

docs.title: Method
docs.text:
1. Place salmon filets in an oven-safe dish.
  2. Whisk together the citrus zest/juice, ginger, honey, salt, pepper, olive oil, and coriander.
  3. Pour the glaze over the salmon filets, coating them evenly.
  4. Marinate & Form Pellicle:
  5. Let sit 30 minutes for flavor infusion.
  6. Remove salmon filets from the glaze (reserve the glaze for basting) and place them on a wire rack over a baking sheet.
  7. Refrigerate uncovered overnight to allow a pellicle (a sticky, tacky surface) to form. This helps smoke adhere and improves texture.
  8. Bake at 375°F (or smoke if desired) for 12–15 minutes, basting occasionally with the reserved glaze, until flaky and cooked to your preference.

Tags: #seafood

docs.title: Shrimp Salad
docs.text:
Delicious Shrimp Salad recipe with Old Bay seasoning and fresh herbs.

Recipe Details

  • Yield: ** 4-6
  • Prep time: ** 20 mins
  • Texture target: TBD
  • Cook time: ** 5 mins

docs.title: For poaching the shrimp
docs.text:
• 1.5 pounds shrimp (31-40 count) – peeled, deveined, and tails removed
  • 1/2 teaspoon baking soda
  • 1/2 teaspoon Diamond Crystal Kosher salt
  • 8 cups water
  • 1 tablespoon fresh lemon juice
  • 2 teaspoons Old Bay seasoning

docs.title: For the sauce
docs.text:
• 1/2 cup finely diced celery
  • 1/4 cup finely diced red onion
  • 1 tablespoon minced dill, plus more to taste
  • 3/4 cup mayonnaise
  • 1/2 teaspoon Old Bay seasoning
  • 1 teaspoon celery seed
  • 2 ounces lemon juice
  • 2 teaspoons Dijon mustard
  • Salt and pepper to taste

docs.title: Poaching the shrimp
docs.text:
1. Mix the shrimp well with the baking soda, salt, and Old Bay seasoning and set aside. Wait 15-20 minutes until boiling. While the shrimp are sitting in the brine, mix the sauce.
  2. Prepare a large bowl of ice water for shocking the shrimp and set aside.
  3. Add the water and lemon juice to a large pot and bring to a boil.
  4. Add the shrimp to the pot and cook for 90 seconds or until they turn slightly opaque. Place the shrimp immediately into the ice water bath to stop the cooking process. Drain the shrimp in a colander and pat dry with paper towels.

docs.title: For the sauce
docs.text:
1. In a large bowl, mix together all of the ingredients. Taste test and adjust salt and pepper if required.
  2. Add the shrimp to the sauce and coat well. Cover with plastic wrap and refrigerate for at least 2 hours but preferably overnight to let the flavors meld.
  3. The next day, for a dryer salad, strain the shrimp through a colander to drain the liquid. Serve immediately. Enjoy!

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• It is recommended to refrigerate overnight. The flavor will be much better and the shrimp salad can be drained to remove excess water.
  • For convenience, cleaned and deveined 31-40 count shrimp were used. Feel free to use shell on shrimp if you desire and peel right after shocking in the ice water bath.
  • Any size shrimp can be used. Larger shrimp will take more time so keep an eye on them. Once they are opaque, they are done and should be shocked in ice water immediately.
  • Leftovers can be kept in the fridge for up to 3 days.

Tags: #seafood, #salad, #shrimp

docs.title: 📂 Sides
docs.text:
Here are the recipes in this collection:

  • Potato Croquettes

docs.title: Potato Croquettes
docs.text:
Recipe Details

  • Yield: ~2–4 servings
  • Texture target: Crisp exterior, fluffy interior
  • Cut style: Squares or short sticks

docs.title: Potato Dough
docs.text:
• 1 lb / 450 g cooked potatoes (about 2 large russets), very well-drained
  • 2 tbsp (28 g) melted butter
  • 1 tsp kosher salt, to start

docs.title: Starches (40–60 g total)
docs.text:
• 20–30 g potato starch
  • 20–30 g tapioca flour

Note: Add more starch only if the dough is sticky.

docs.title: Seasoning Mix (makes ~2–3 tbsp)
docs.text:
• 1 tbsp BBQ rub (salt level varies—adjust accordingly)
  • 1 tsp smoked paprika
  • 1 tsp chili powder
  • 1 tsp sugar
  • ½ tsp garlic powder
  • ½ tsp onion powder
  • ¼ tsp cayenne (or less, to taste)
  • 1 tsp dried parsley

docs.title: 1. Cook and Dry the Potatoes
docs.text: Boil until fully tender. Drain thoroughly, then return to the hot pot for 1–2 minutes to steam off excess moisture. Drier potatoes = stronger fries.

docs.title: 2. Mash Ultra-Smooth
docs.text: Mash until completely lump-free. A ricer is ideal.

docs.title: 3. Make the Dough
docs.text: While the potatoes are still warm, mix in salt and melted butter. Add starches gradually until the dough is pliable like playdough—holds together and does not stick to your hands.

docs.title: 4. Shape
docs.text: Press dough onto parchment into a slab ⅜–½ inch (8–12 mm) thick. Cut into squares or sticks.

docs.title: 5. Freeze (Critical Step)
docs.text: Freeze 30–60 minutes until firm. This prevents breakage during frying.

docs.title: 6. Fry
docs.text: Heat neutral oil to 375°F / 190°C. Fry in small batches until deep golden and crisp.

docs.title: 7. Season Immediately
docs.text:
Toss hot fries with seasoning mix. Serve right away.

Troubleshooting

  • Falls apart in oil? Dough too wet or under-frozen.
    • Fix: Dry potatoes more, add a bit more starch, freeze longer.
  • Gummy interior? Too much tapioca or oil too cool.
    • Fix: Reduce tapioca share, keep oil hot.
  • Not crisping? Oil too cool or pieces too thick.
    • Fix: Fry hotter or cut thinner.

Notes

  • Russet potatoes give the best structure.
  • Yukon Golds work but may need slightly more starch.
  • Squares stay creamier; sticks get crispier edges.
